metadata.subject: Economic Policy for the Information Economy symposium paper

organizations: Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City
financial_entities: Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City

relationships.description: Summers served as U.S. Secretary of the Treasury during Clinton's administration
Summers was former president of Harvard University
DeLong is a professor of economics at UC Berkeley

analysis.purpose: To discuss economic contradictions in capitalist theory facing new information technologies
analysis.significance: Academic economic analysis of how capitalist systems may struggle with near-zero marginal cost technologies

notable_quotes: This catch-22 is the inherent contradiction that underlies capitalist theory and practice
contemporary economists are once again peering into the contradictory workings of the capitalist system, unsure of how to make the market economy function without self-destructing

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion present - purely academic economic discussion

illegal_activity.description: No illegal activity discussed - this is academic economic analysis

public_knowledge.context: Academic economic symposium paper discussing theoretical economic concepts

analysis.summary: This document contains excerpts from an academic economic paper presented at a Federal Reserve symposium in 2001, discussing the inherent contradictions in capitalist theory when facing new information technologies that create near-zero marginal cost economies, referencing economists Lawrence Summers and J. Bradford DeLong.
